From that time, I was treated with more respect than before, and when we were weary of chatting it grow∣ing late, they gave me the choice of a bed by my self, where I slept all night without awaking: To make short, my dear heart, we all got safe to our jour∣nies end, I was conducted to the maid's Mothers house, where while a mans black suit, which was with other things in the Cloak bag, fitting for me, I sent to Cane for a Perriwig, a Hat, a Sword, and all other things fitting to make me a compleat Cavaller, having all things ready to appear in publick, after I had return'd the people of the House many thanks for all their kind∣nesses to me, I went to Cane, where I was no sooner arriv'd, but I got a Mes∣seng, who carried me a Letter to my Scotch Lover, from whom I thought, I should get a better account
then any body else could give me of all my concerns: Not doubting, but that his Love to me, would have made him very inqulsitive after me, and that the same love would quickly bring him to me. If I did but in the least desire it: Not doubting, but to shake him off a∣gain, when I should think it convenient. The Letter was much to this purpose.

LETTER.P: WHen I have assur'd you, that all which I have lately acted, was on∣ly in order to preserve my self for you, I pre∣sume, I shall not need to make use of any o∣ther inducements to bring you to me, then to let you know where I am. Therefore I invite you to make all the haste you can possible to come to the white horse in Cane, where you will find she that is only yours,

DIV2.P:
The Messenger that carried it, found him desperately ill, in so much that he thought, he could not live to the Jour∣nies end, that he had been so overjoy'd at the reception of my Letter, that he had immediately given order to get a
Litter ready to carry him the next morning out of Town, to take the air, as he pretended, with that he gave me a Letter from him, and I assure you, Sir, continu'd the fellow: No Lover, could have made more Caresses to a Let∣ter, from his beloved Mistress, than he made of yours, which he believ'd he had seen him kiss twenty times, and read as often over in private; and that every body in the house were wondring at so great a change in him, which made them very inquisitive to know of me, whether it came not from a young Gen∣tlewoman. I told my Messenger, to take of all suspition, that though it came from me, yet, that there was such news in it from a Gentlewoman; as would as much please him But since he is so ill as you say, I have a mind to meet him upon the Rode, least his death should prevent me from accomplishing that good office which I have promised my kinswoman to do for her having thus said to the Messenger, I opened the Letter, in which, I read as fol∣lows

LETTER.L: MY dearest, dearest Dear, thy half dead Sawndy.
By strength of Love with Litter and burnt Brandy.
Will run through, Fire, Air, Earth, and Water too.
Through thick and thin, over Boot, over Shoo.
To come to thee: with sickness I'm so prest.
I can no more, let Porter tell the rest.

DIV2.P: By this I found though he could not leave off his Plague of Rhime, that he was really very ill, of which I did inform the Messenger; who told me that he had swounded twice away the Writing of those few lines, about which he had spent two hours time at least. This made me employ this fel∣low, to get me immediately a Horse, to be going that very day to meet him.

Mean time I was very well pleas'd within my self at all this, by which I found I should the sooner and the easier compass my ends, then I could
ever have imagin'd, if I did but find him alive. The fellow having got me a Horse: We both presently set forwards, we were got a little above halfway to Roan, where we met with my poor Lover, who was laid in bed in a Inn of a Market Town: Not being able to pursue his Journey any further. He had been so prudent, not to men∣tion a word of me to any body; there∣fore, when I came to his bedside, tak∣ing him by the hand, I did softly whis∣per in his ear, that I was his Susetta, come to meet him in that dis∣guise, that I might not be discover'd: He presently started up, holding me fast by the hand with both his, and having given order that every body in the room, should retire: He did endeavour to express, as well as he could, what joy he receiv'd at the sight of me. Though he fear'd that it was too late to continue long, the grief which he had taken for my loss, having come so near his heart, that it had reduc'd him to that sad extremity, in which I saw him. Adding that his greatest trou∣ble
had been how to order things so, that in case I should ever be found again, I should inherit all that he would leave to me at his decease: That I should now pass for a Ne∣phew of his, though he had no re∣lation that he knew of, and that he would forthwith make his Will, but if it were possible, he would willingly be remov'd to some private house out of Town, because that the perpetual noise of that place he was in would not let him take any rest. And so he concluded, I having return'd him many thanks, and once more assur'd him of my affections, we broke off our private discourse: He having bid me call for Megerlain, to whom he gave order to get things ready to remove pesently: He desired that I should retire to take my Rest, while he would endeavour to do the like, to make him the more able to endure the Removing; with that he turn'd to sleep, and I went to another Room, where having call'd for a Pe and Ink to Write for an E∣minent Physician at Paris, to come
to my Unkle (as I call'd him) I Writ that Letter, which brought you to me. Not long after, I was call'd to him again, he not being able to rest for the Noise, he bid me take care of his Removal, which I presently order'd: We were no sooner come to the House, which I had caus'd to be taken for him, but he call'd for all the pesons be∣longing to it, and, in the presence of them all, he did declare, that I was his Nephew, and next Heir at Law, and that he would have every body, follow my directions.

This was the place wherein I had f the happiness to embrace my Dear Le Noble, who, I hope, will not have the worse opinion of his poor Susetta, for having given him so true and just an account of her whole Life, since it was in obedience to his Com∣mands.

Le Noble having thank'd her and assured her, that if it were possible to Love her more then he did already, the Candidness she had us'd in the delivery of her own story, and the
freeness which he found in all her other discourses and actions, would oll o him it. That he intreated her to believe, that he really and cordially did love her, and would e∣ver continue so to do, with that Su∣setta seeming desirous to sleep, Le No∣ble having taken his leave of her, was retiring into his Chamber, which was on the other side of the house, when Susetta, calling him back, told him, that hence forwards she would discharge her self on him, of the troublesome office of Purse∣bearer, so desired that he should take that which lay upon the Table along with him, and the Writings of concern: Le Noble reply'd, I will obey you in all things; and thrusting his hand into the Purse, he took out a handful of Gold and Silver mix'd together, and which laying upon the Table, but least you should be too troublesome, continued he, with frequent demanding for Pins and such like trifles, let this lye by you, to supply you with such dayly occasions, and presently draw∣ing
the door close after him, to take from her all occasion of reply, he retired to his Chamber, where I will leave him till the next Morn∣ing, which will produce some New Adventure, wherewith to begin the Second Part.

DIV1.TRAILER: The End of the First Part.
